title: Developers: Transcending To The Next Level

content.text: I’m in the zone, a few layers deep into my code refactoring. My phone vibrates, dammit. I take a quick look at the number, it’s unrecognised. I'm feeling a bit ominous as to who this could be, but I pick up anyway.
“Hi, is that Nathan?”
“Speaking.”
“Hi there, I’m calling from Generic Recruitment Specialists, your CV has just come up on my screen!”
“Oh.”
“Yep, I’m very keen to have a chat about a few roles I’m looking at now.”
“Uh… Sorry I have to go”
*click*

This is a pretty regular occurence nowadays. Recruiters are understandably relentless. But I remember when I was fresh out of university, and would probably have taken any IT related job. In fact, I did, and it was to date the worst professional experience of my life (never work in banking).

Right now I’m in a great role, and looking forward to my next one; where I’ll work less, earn more and have more freedom and influence. So how did I get to a point where I have a real abundance of opportunities to choose from and amazing people to work with?
Disrupt

Here’s the deal, just doing your job - and only your job time and time again will not elevate your status. Good programmers are at least a tinge lazy, and devs should be spending their time improving and optimising their own workflow to make their own life easier.

In the past I have worked with people who somehow give 100%, all day long, fully focus from 9 till 5. It takes a lot of energy - and who wants to have to work like a dog and toil all day long for recognition? Yes everyone would like a workhorse in their ranks who they can offload their tedious tasks to. But that isn't promotion material. Where devs can concentrate on adding value to any business, is in providing unique insights or going over and above expectations.
Overdeliver, innovate and generally just push.

A great example: one company I was with had me doing a very tedious content updating task. Basically I was given a list of new assets every week, and I had to go through a number of pages and update the HTML to reflect the changes. This was a horrible and infamously manual process that many before me had worked on, and complained about, time after time.

I made sure I got the work done, but I also spent approximately half the time building a customised super lightweight CMS in order to automate this whole task. After around a week, I had built something from scratch that made this tedious task pretty trivial, enjoyable even. As part of the process I had also learnt a new language (Node.js) and some new concepts and ways of working.

Slowly over time I shared what I’d built with my colleagues and they really liked it. My role changed from performing the updates to supporting the application. But the real gain for me was the impression and perception I’d imposed of being an innovator. When the next project with Node came along you can guess who was first on the list to work on it.
Build Stuff
You must have personal projects.

I build stuff all the time. I have numerous orphaned experiments, many of which I can’t even remember until the domain comes up for renewal again. WLL.space is just an example, but each of the experiments that I’ve produced has taught me more about building, about design, about JavaScript etc. Learning on the job is fine, but it’s not enough to excel - I cannot emphasize this enough, you must have personal projects.

At work, unless you are working on an amazing digital product team like at Spotify or Uber, you are unlikely to be pushing the boundary of your digital or technical knowledge. Usually devs are consigned to delivering whatever project the client needs. If we don’t have personal projects, we are therefore a passenger in our technical development - at the whim of whatever language or framework our superior decides is to be our destiny.

Building projects is, then, in effect building ourself. Taking charge of the path we want to take and being adept enough that when the opportunity comes, we can take on the work confidently or apply for that job in the area we want without being a total n00b.
Visibility, Assertiveness and Communication

One of the major problems historically with developers is their communication skills. Some of my recent learnings have been around the power of speaking my mind. I am always trying to push the boundary and provide innovative solutions, but it isn't always the case that I'll be recognised for my very noble work. That’s absolutely fine, because if I don’t communicate the job I am doing then why should anyone else bother to take note?
Challenge, challenge hard and challenge often.

If you have built something, then take the time to show it to your colleagues. If you deserve a promotion, recognise it yourself and proceed to directly ask for it. If there is a problem with your project, some interesting (bad) tech decisions that could affect you later, challenge it, challenge it hard and do so often.

When we make our opinion known, people respect us for it. It’s no good grumbling about this or that, if something is wrong, then we need to say it. Honesty and clarity are usually appreciated. Our seniors may not always be so well informed, but they have to make hard decisions anyway. We better enable others to take action on our behalf.

Bear in mind, there are some simple nuances; being assertive is not the same as complaining or moaning it’s about clearly communicating our thoughts and wants. Ultimately we can only be respected and heard if we are providing value at the same time. Working effectively and great communication go hand in hand.
